title: Carabanchel Prison
text:
Carabanchel Prison was constructed by <a href="political%20prisoner">political prisoner</a>s after the <a href="Spanish%20Civil%20War">Spanish Civil War</a> between 1940 and 1944 in the <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a> neighbourhood of <a href="Carabanchel">Carabanchel</a>. It was one of the biggest <a href="prisons">prisons</a> in Europe until its closure in 1998. The structure followed the <a href="panopticon">panopticon</a> model devised by <a href="Jeremy%20Bentham">Jeremy Bentham</a> in 1785.
History.
During "<a href="caudillo">caudillo</a>" <a href="Francisco%20Franco">Francisco Franco</a>'s <a href="Spanish%20State">Spanish State</a> (1936–1975) the prison hosted a large community of political prisoners, which included members of socialist, anarchist, communist and marxist political parties and union leaders. Notable inmates included <a href="Marcelino%20Camacho">Marcelino Camacho</a> (leader of the Communist clandestine union <a href="Comisiones%20Obreras">Comisiones Obreras</a>) and the rest of top-rank members of it imprisoned as a result of the <a href="Process%201001">Process 1001</a>, <a href="Juli%C3%A1n%20Ariza">Julián Ariza</a> (member also of the same union), <a href="Nicol%C3%A1s%20Redondo">Nicolás Redondo</a> (leader of <a href="Workers%27%20General%20Union">Workers' General Union</a>), <a href="Eduardo%20Saborido">Eduardo Saborido</a>, <a href="Sim%C3%B3n%20S%C3%A1nchez%20Montero">Simón Sánchez Montero</a> (<a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Spain%20%28main%29">Communist</a> leader, who served 25 years in prison), <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Mar%C3%ADa%20Ruiz%20Gallard%C3%B3n">José María Ruiz Gallardón</a> (monarchist opponent to the Francoist State and father of the former <a href="Minister%20of%20Justice%20%28Spain%29">Minister of Justice</a> <a href="Alberto%20Ruiz%20Gallard%C3%B3n">Alberto Ruiz Gallardón</a>), <a href="Nicol%C3%A1s%20Sartorius">Nicolás Sartorius</a>, <a href="Ram%C3%B3n%20Tamames">Ramón Tamames</a>, <a href="Enrique%20M%C3%BAgica">Enrique Múgica</a> and <a href="Enrique%20Curiel">Enrique Curiel</a> (Communist activists), <a href="Miguel%20Boyer">Miguel Boyer</a> (<a href="Spanish%20Socialist%20Workers%27%20Party">Socialist</a> activist and a minister later), <a href="Fernando%20S%C3%A1nchez-Drag%C3%B3">Fernando Sánchez-Dragó</a>, <a href="Miguel%20Gila">Miguel Gila</a>, <a href="Fernando%20Savater">Fernando Savater</a>, <a href="Fernando%20Arrabal">Fernando Arrabal</a>, <a href="Confederacion%20Nacional%20del%20Trabajo">CNT</a> member <a href="Lu%C3%ADs%20Andr%C3%A9s%20Edo">Luís Andrés Edo</a> and would-be Franco assassins <a href="Stuart%20Christie">Stuart Christie</a> and <a href="Fernando%20Carballo%20Blanco">Fernando Carballo Blanco</a>. Colombian Cocaine Kingpins <a href="Jorge%20Luis%20Ochoa%20V%C3%A1squez">Jorge Luis Ochoa Vásquez</a> and <a href="Gilberto%20Rodr%C3%ADguez%20Orejuela">Gilberto Rodríguez Orejuela</a> where also imprisoned in Carabanchel in the mid 1980's. After Franco's death, only common criminals and members of the Basque separatist group <a href="ETA%20%28separatist%20group%29">ETA</a> and other paramilitary groups remained.
After its abandonment, the building was heavily looted and was inhabited by marginal communities. Most of the prison walls were covered with graffiti, some of them very elaborate. A lengthy debate took place between the neighbours from Carabanchel and <a href="Aluche">Aluche</a>, who wanted a hospital and other public facilities to be built in the area, and the local authorities, who want to privatize the land for housing development. The neighbours also wanted part of the prison to be preserved.
Finally in July 2008, local and national government reached an agreement on the future of the prison lot, projecting to build 650 apartments, a hospital, green zones and government buildings on the former prison grounds. Despite protests the entire Carabanchel complex was demolished in late 2008.
